The second step is to obtain the sensitivity of a disease’s incidence to climate variables (e.g., temperature, humidity, precipitation, etc.) for each group ( i.e., the exposure and non-exposure groups). The sensitivity of a disease’s incidence to climate variables, hereinafter referred to as sensitivity, is defined as the slope of the linear model created by regressing disease incidence against corresponding climate variables. This slope reflects the change of disease incidence in response to a given change (usually one unit) in a climate variable:
